bibl.title: Petitioner v. Defendant. Type of document
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

div1.p: UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON NORTHERN DIVISION.
In the Matter of the Application of MAC FOCK for a Writ of Habeas Corpus.
No. 2500 RETURN TO WRIT.
To the Honorable Judge of the United States District Court for the Western District of Washington:

Comes now Ellis De Bruler, Commissioner of Immigration at the Port of Seattle, and makes this return to the writ of habeas corpus heretofore issues in the above entitled matter and produces in court the body of said Mac Fock and alleges as follows:
I.

He admits the allegations of paragraphs one and two of the petitions for the writ except that he denies the charge under which Mac Fock is held is illegal, and he denies that he is held for deportation as one already in the country but alleges the fact to be that he, the said Mac Fock is held as one about to be returned to China without having been granted admission into the United States.
II.
He admits the allegation of paragraph three of the petition.
III.
He admits the allegations of paragraph four of the
petition down to and including the words "United States" on line five of the page two of said petition and denies each and every other allegation therein contained.
IV.

Answering paragraph five of said petition, he admits the allegations of lines 13 to 18 of page 2 inclusive, except that denies that the said Mac Fock has done than to claim to excercise rights of citizenship for seventeen years. He denies each and every other allegation therein contained except as expressly admitted in the affirmative matter hereinafter pleaded.
V.

He admits that Mac Fock is the same person referred to in a certain certificate of Felix W. McGettrick, who was the United States Commissioner in the State of Vermont on the 12th day of June, 1896, which certficate is hereinafter more fully referred to, and he admits that said Felix W. McGettrick was at the time duly qualifed as such United States Commissioner to perform all acts proper to be performed by such Commissioner, but he denies that said certificate constitutes any order of discharge or that the said Mac Fock holds, or has any order of discharge whatsoever. He denes each and every other allegation contained in paragraph six not expressly admitted in the affirmative matter herein after pleaded.
For a further affirmative return to said writ, Ellis De Bruler alleges:
I.

That he, the said Ellis De Bruler, as Commissioner of Immigration aforesaid, holds the said Mac Fock as an alien immigrant under an order of deportation to the Republic of China, of which the said Mac Fock is a native and citizen and from which he came to the United States arriving at the Port of Seattle on the Steamship Ixion on the 14th day of April, 1913; that the said Mac Fock upon his arrival in said Port of Seattle, applied for admission into the United States as a returning native born American of Chinese descent; that thereupon a hearing was had before the respondent of Commissioner of Immigration upon evidence both oral and documentary, duly offered in said matter; that said documentary evidence includes a certain alleged certificate then in the possession of the said Mac Fock, the original of which constitutes a part of the original record of the hearing of said Mac Fock before the Bureau of Immigration of the Department of Labor. Said oral evidence includes the statement of the said Mac Fock under oath that he was born in China, said statement having been made by him twice directly and positively under oath (see page 1 for certificate and pages 22 and 27 for statement as to place of birth); that said certificate is the document referred to in the petition for the writ of habeas corpus as an order of discharge, and that said certificate is neither an order nor an original record of judgment before the Commissioner, nor a certified or authenticated copy of any record of judgment before
said Commissioner. The full original record of the hearing in all matters pertaining thereto before the Commissioner of Immigration at Seattle, and of the appeal to the Secretary of Labor, is filed herewith. Said original record is the record of the proceedings and on which said Mac Fock is held. That as appears by said record the respondent herein as Commissioner of Immigration duly considered all evidence offered and thereupon the application of the said Mac Fock for admission into the United States was denied and he was ordered returned to China. That it further appears therefrom that the said Mac Fock thereupon appealed from said decision of said Commissioner to the Secretary of Labor and the said Secretary of Labor, after due consideration of said appeal on the 3rd day of June, 1913, affirmed the decision of the said Commissioner of Immigration.
WHEREFORE, Respondent asks that the writ of habeas corpus herein be discharged and the petition dismissed.
Ellis De Bruler
Commissioner of Immigration.
E B Brakury
Assistant United States Attorney.
United States of America Western District of Washington } SS.

Ellis De Bruler, being first duly sworn on oath, deposes and says: That he is the Commissioner of Immigration at the Port of Seattle and respondent in the above entitled action; that he has read the foregoing return to the writ of habeas corpus herein, knows the contents thereof and that the same is true as he verily believes.
Ellis De Bruler
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 2nd day of July, 1913. Edm Lakin
Deputy Clerk, U.S. District Court. Western District of Washington.
